Nopinone is a fine chemical used in many areas of the chemical industry. A relatively new method of its synthesis is Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of myrtenal to 6,6-dimethyl-bicyclo[3,1,1]-hept-2-en-2-ol formate and its subsequent hydrolysis to nopinone. This study deals with preparing mixed oxides modified with tin and tested them as catalysts for this reaction. Besides the influence of different reaction conditions, the research was aimed at the influence of the catalyst type, the method of its modification and the amount of metal incorporated into its structure. The possibility of repeated use of the prepared catalysts was also tested. Total conversion of myrtenal and selectivity to nopinone of 93% was achieved after 2 h of the reaction using the catalyst based on mixed oxide with the molar ratio of Mg/Al ions equals 2 modified by 5 wt% of tin. This catalyst can be used repeatedly in at least three reaction cycles. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Baeyer-Villiger oxidation Myrtenal Nopinone Tin-modified mixed oxide Hydrotalcite Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Baeyer-Villiger oxidation is a reaction in which an ester is formed from acyclic ketones or aldehydes using peroxide or peroxyacid as an oxidizing agent, or a lactone is formed if the starting substance is a cyclic ketone [1]. It was first discovered in 1899 by the German chemists Adolf von Baeyer and Victor Villiger. Baeyer and Villiger successfully used peroxosulfuric acid to form the corresponding lactones from camphor, menthone, and tetrahydrocarvone [2,3]. Nowadays, this reaction is used not only for the synthesis of fragrances, but also for the synthesis of steroids and the preparation of monomers for polymerization [4]. For Baeyer – Villiger oxidation, many different peroxyacids or peroxides can be used as oxidizing agents. The use of strong peroxyacids does not require the presence of a catalyst in the reaction mixture. In contrast, using weaker peroxyacids and peroxides requires the simultaneous addition of a catalyst [5]. Among the most used peroxyacids belong trifluoroperacetic acid, meta-chloroperoxybenzoic acid, performic acid, peroxybenzoic acid, peracetic acid. Among the most used peroxides is hydrogen peroxide [2,6]. Both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts can be used for BV oxidation. Homogeneous catalysts include metal complexes based on platinum, rhenium, palladium, etc [7–9]. From the group of heterogeneous catalysts, the most used are zeolites [10–12], and mesoporous materials, such as MCM-41 [13–16] and MCM-48 [17–19], with incorporated titanium, tin, iron, or nickel, as well as metal-modified mixed oxides based on hydrotalcites [20–24]. The advantage of heterogeneous catalysts is their easy separation from the reaction mixture. Therefore the catalysts could be more easily recycled. Nopinone is a bicyclic keto compound, similar to myrtenal ( Fig. 1). Nopinone is a colorless liquid utilized as a starting material for synthesizing chiral ligands or compounds that may have a pharmacological effect. Nopinone can be prepared by oxidation of β-pinene using potassium permanganate, or by its ozonolysis [25]. As an alternative method for the synthesis of nopinone, the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of myrtenal using hydrogen peroxide as an oxidizing agent is attracting some interest. Corma [26] tested 2 catalysts for this reaction - Sn-MCM-41 and Sn-Beta zeolite. When using Sn-Beta zeolite, only 10% myrtenal conversion was achieved after 1 h of reaction, and this number did not change much when the reaction was carried out for a longer time. The main product formed was formate, with the selectivity of 67%. Other products include nopinone and myrtenic acid with the selectivity of 16% resp. 7%. Therefore, Sn-Beta zeolite is more active for BV oxidation than for subsequent hydrolysis. If Sn-MCM-41 was used as a catalyst, relatively higher conversion approx. 40% was achieved after 1 h of reaction. The selectivity in favor of nopinone increased to 74%, which suggests that this material is active for both reaction steps and can be used for the synthesis of nopinone. Interesting results were obtained using meta-chloroperoxybenzoic acid (m-CPBA) as an oxidizing agent and without the presence of a catalyst. In this case, a higher conversion, namely 16% after 1 h of reaction, was achieved compared to 10% when using the combination of Sn-Beta zeolite and hydrogen peroxide. The main products formed were formate and myrtenic acid in a ratio of 1:1.5. This could mean that m-CPBA, both as a catalyst and as an oxidizing agent, is more active for the first step of nopinone synthesis. We focused on synthesizing tin-modified mixed oxides and testing their catalytic activity for the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of myrtenal to formate and its subsequent hydrolysis to nopinone. The mixed oxides or hydrotalcites as catalysts for BV oxidation of ketones [11,27–30] have already been described in literature, but there is no many information about using such catalysts for BV oxidation of aldehydes. That is why our group applies to research in this area [31–33]. Two mechanisms of Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of ketones using hydrotalcites as catalysts and hydrogen peroxide as an oxidizing agent can be found in the literature. For the first method, the presence of a solvent containing a nitrile group (benzonitrile or acetonitrile) is necessary [4,21,34]. The reaction begins with hydrogen peroxide attacking the Brønsted basic site on the catalyst surface to form a hydroperoxide compound, which subsequently attacks the nitrile to form a peroxycarboximidic acid intermediate. Then, this intermediate attacks the ketone adsorbed on the Lewis acid site in the catalyst. The resulting Criegee adduct is subsequently rearranged to the final product [34]. For the second reaction mechanism, the presence of a solvent is not necessary, but the catalyst used should be modified with metals capable of activating the carbonyl group of the aldehyde or ketone, e.g. tin. At the beginning of the reaction, the ketone is coordinated to the Lewis acid site. That leads to activation of the carbonyl group. Subsequently, the hydrogen peroxide attacks the more electrophilic carbonyl carbon atom. In this way, the Criegee intermediate is formed, which then rearranges into the resulting product [35]. The second mechanism is mainly described for BV oxidation catalyzed by Sn-Beta zeolites and Sn-MCM-41 [10,36]. As an oxidizing agent for BV oxidation of myrtenal, hydrogen peroxide was chosen (Fig. 1). The optimization of the reaction conditions was a part of this work as well. Besides the comparative study of catalytic activity of modified mixed oxides either by impregnation or coprecipitation, the catalyst modified by both methods was also tested in the model reaction. To compare the obtained data with those presented in the literature, Sn-MCM-41 was selected as a referential catalyst for the BV oxidation of myrtenal to nopinone. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis and Modification of Catalysts Myrtenal (purity 97%) was used as it was purchased from Merck without any treatment. Nopinone (98%) as a standard, meta-chloroperoxybenzoic acid (77%), benzonitrile, and N,N-dimethylacetamide were also purchased from Merck. All metal salts used for the preparation of the catalysts, acetonitrile, diethyl ether, ethanol, ethyl acetate, methyl acetoacetate were purchased from Lachner. Hydrogen peroxide (50% solution in water) was purchased from Carl Roth. Hydrogen peroxide (30% solution in water), tin(II) chloride dihydrate, and all other solvents were purchased from Penta. Hydrotalcites with molar ratios MgAl = 2:1, 2.5:1, 3:1, and 3.5:1 were prepared by co-precipitation method at constant pH of 9.5 ± 0.1 according to the procedure reported in our previous study [31]. The prepared hydrotalcites were calcined at 400 °C for 5 h to give mixed oxides and subsequently modified by impregnation of tin as it was reported in the literature [21]. Mixed oxide and SnCl2∙2 H2O were added to a 1:1 methanol-water solution, tempered to the desired temperature and stirred for 24 h. The reaction mixture was then filtered and washed - first with water, then with methanol. The resulting catalysts were dried overnight at 110 °C and calcined at 400 °C for 5 h. The part of tin modified mixed oxides was also rehydrated. 100 ml of distilled water was used for 1 g of calcined hydrotalcite. Distilled water was previously boiled, cooled to room temperature, and degassed by nitrogen for 15 min. After adding the catalyst, this mixture was stirred under a nitrogen atmosphere for 90 min. The water was subsequently evaporated on a vacuum evaporator at a temperature of 55 °C and a pressure of 60 mbar under an argon atmosphere. The hydrotalcite thus prepared was kept in a desiccator and was processed until the next day. The abbreviation rHT was used in the text for designation of rehydrated hydrotalcites. The preparation of Mg-Al-Sn (II) layered double hydroxides with the Mg/Al/Sn molar ratio 3/0.75/0.25 prepared by the co-precipitation method was also described in literature [31]. The prepared catalyst was calcined for 5 h at 400 °C to get mixed oxide. Part of it was subsequently modified by impregnation of 5 wt% of tin using the same procedure as was described earlier. The MCM-41 catalyst was prepared by hydrothermal synthesis [37] and modified by Sn using SnCl2. Impregnation was followed by calcination at 350 °C. 2.2 Catalysts Characterization 2.2.1 X-ray fluorescence analysis (XRF) The determination of the composition of the catalysts was performed on an ARL 9400 XP sequential WD-XRF spectrometer (Thermo ARL, Ecublens, Switzerland) using X-ray fluorescence analysis (XRF). This apparatus is equipped with an Rh anode end-window X-ray tube of type 4GN fitted with a 75 µm Be window. All measurements of the intensities of the spectral lines of the elements were carried out under vacuum using the WinXRF program. The generating settings-collimator-crystal-detector combinations were optimized for all 79 measured elements with an analysis time of 6 s per element. Data evaluation was performed with Uniquant 4 software tool. 2.2.2 X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was used to determine the crystal structure and crystallinity of the prepared catalysts. The measurements were performed at room temperature on an X-Pert3 Powder θ-θ powder diffractometer in a Bragg-Brentan parafocusing geometry using CuKα radiation wavelength (λ = 1.5418 Å, U = 40 kV, I = 30 mA). Data were scanned using an ultrafast 1D PIXCEL detector in the angular range 5–60° (2θ) with a measurement step of 0.013° (2θ) and a reading time of 56.86 with step-1. The obtained data were evaluated by the HighScore Plus 4.0. 2.2.3 Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) The catalysts were also characterized with scanning electron microscopy (SEM) on JSM-IT500HR instrument from Jeol group. The electron microscope was used to determine the texture of the surface of the samples. To confirm Sn distribution in catalyst samples, energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) was used to find the elemental maps of the samples. 2.2.4 Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) Acid-base properties were measured by temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of both CO2 and pyridine. TPD was carried out using a Micromeritics Instrument, AutoChem II 2920. For desorbed CO2/pyridine detection, both a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and quadrupole mass spectrometer (MKS Cirrus 2 Analyzer) with a capillary coupling system were used. The catalyst sample (0.06 g) was placed in a quartz U-shaped tube. Prior to gas adsorption, the catalyst was heated under a helium flow (30 ml min–1) up to 400 °C and kept at 400 °C for 60 min to remove impurities from the sample. In the following step, the sample was cooled down to an adsorption temperature of 40 °C (in case of CO2) or 150 °C (in case of pyridine). Measured pulses of sorption gas (pulse volume, 5 ml) were injected into the helium gas and carried through the catalyst sample until adsorption saturation. Then the sample was purged with helium for 60 min to remove physisorbed gas. Afterward, the linear temperature program (10 °C min–1) was started at a temperature of 40 °C and the sample was heated up to a temperature of 600 °C. The amounts of desorbed CO2 were determined by calibrating the intensity of the 44 (in case of CO2) or 79 (in case of pyridine) amu MS response. 2.2.5 Nitrogen Adsorption Measurements The measurement of the specific surface area, adsorption pore volume and pore size distribution of tin modified mixed oxides was performed by nitrogen physisorption on an Autosorb-iQ-KR/MP-XR instrument from Quantachrome. Before the analysis, the samples were degassed at 110 °C for 24 h. Measurements were carried out at the boiling temperature of liquid nitrogen (77 K). The values of the specific surface area were calculated according to the course of the measured nitrogen isotherm in the area of relative pressures from 0 to 0.2. The data were processed using the BET-equation, thereby obtaining coefficients from which the specific surface area of each sample was determined. For most samples, the specific surface was evaluated from a 4-point isotherm. The entire isotherm was measured for five key samples. The NLDFT method was used to determine the pore size distribution. 2.3 Catalytic experiments The Baeyer-Villiger oxidation was carried out in a 25 ml magnetically stirred round bottom flask equipped with a reflux condenser. In a typical experiment, 0.1 g of the prepared catalyst was added to a solution of 0.5 g of the myrtenal (3.3 mmol) and 3 g of solvent. The reaction mixture was stirred and tempered to 80 °C. The required amount of oxidizing agent (3.2 molar equivalents) was divided into 12 parts and dosed sequentially at 10-minute intervals. The reaction was started by additing the first dose of 50% aqueous hydrogen peroxide solution. Samples of the reaction mixture were taken in regular intervals (just before the insertion of the first dose of oxidizing agent into the reaction mixture and then at 10, 30, 60, 90, 120, 180, 240 and 300 min), centrifuged to remove the catalyst, and analyzed using a Varian CP 3800 gas chromatograph with a nonpolar CP-SIL 8 column (30 m long, diameter: 0.25 mm, stationary phase film thickness: 0.25 µm) an autosampler and FID detector. The carrier gas was nitrogen. Identification of the reaction products was performed on a Shimadzu GC 2010 gas chromatograph with a Shimadzu GC-MS QP 2010 Ultra mass detector (non-polar column DB-5-ms, 35 m long, diameter: 0.20 mm, stationary phase film thickness: 0.33 µm). The carrier gas was helium. 2.4 Evaluation of results The conversion X (%) of the starting material (A) was calculated according to Eq. (1): (1) X A % = ( c A , 0 − c A , t ) c A , 0 ∙ 100 where c A,0 (%) is the analytical concentration of myrtenal at the beginning of the reaction, c A,t (%) is the analytical concentration of myrtenal in the sample taken at time t. The selectivity S (%) to desired products was calculated using Eq. (2): (2) S ( % ) = ∑ c desired products ∑ c all products where c desired products signifies the analytical concentration of the desired reaction products (formate and nopinone) and c all products signifies the analytical concentration of all reaction products. 2.5 Recycling of catalyst Catalyst reusability was tested using two methods of catalyst treatment after the first use in the reaction: drying at 110 °C and calcination at 400 °C. After use in the reaction, the catalyst was filtered off, washed with the same solvent as used in the reaction, dried overnight at 110 °C. After such treatment, it was either reused in the reaction as obtained or was further calcined in air at 400 °C for 5 h after drying and then used in the reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization Mixed oxides modified by tin and Sn-MCM-41 were prepared by impregnation or co-precipitation method according to the procedures described in the experimental. All prepared catalysts were initially analyzed by available analytical methods. Table 1 summarizes the results of some basic analyses, which include information about catalysts composition such as molar ratio Mg/Al, SnO2 content, specific surface area and acid-base properties. SnO2 content in the catalysts determined by XRF was slightly higher than desired. When comparing the unmodified mixed oxides, slight differences between the acid-base properties and the specific surface area values can be observed. Mixed oxides with a lower ratio of Mg/Al are more basic. When increasing the molar ratio of Mg/Al from 3 to 3.5, the basicity decreased by more than 10%. With increasing Al content in the catalyst, the increasing trend in acidity is also observable. Catalysts with a lower Mg/Al ratio (2 and 2.5) showed about 23% higher specific surface area. The data given in Table 1 show, that with increasing SnO2 content in the prepared catalysts, the concentration of acid centers increased and the concentration of basic centers decreased. No apparent dependence was noticed between the values of the specific surface area and the amount of impregnated tin. The mixed oxide modified by 5% of tin had the largest surface area. The temperature at which the materials were modified also slightly affected the catalysts properties. When mixed oxide with a molar ratio of Mg/Al ions of 2 (MO2) was impregnated with tin at a higher temperature, a significant decrease in the specific surface area was observed. However, a similar trend was not recorded for mixed oxide MO3. For all catalysts except 3Sn-MO3imp80 modified at 80 °C, the number of basic centers decreased compared to catalysts modified at room temperature. When mixed oxide MO2 was modified with 3% and 5% of tin, the impregnation at a higher temperature also led to a decrease in the amount of acid centers. On the contrary, for mixed oxide MO3, acid centers increased at higher modification temperatures, in the case of 5Sn-MO3imp80, even by almost 40%. The mixed oxide prepared by the coprecipitation method (10Sn-MOcpm) has completely different acid-base properties. This catalyst contained a high concentration of basic sites, comparable to unmodified mixed oxides and significantly higher than mixed oxides modified by impregnation, including 5Sn-(10Sn-MOcpm)imp25 catalyst, which was prepared by the coprecipitation method and additionally impregnated with 5% of tin. On the other hand, the acidity of 10Sn-MOcpm catalyst is the lowest of all the tin-modified mixed oxides. Its total acidity value and SBET are close to the unmodified MO3.5 catalyst of a similar Mg/Al ratio. By comparing the specific surface area of the catalysts 10Sn-MOcpm and 5Sn-(10Sn-MOcpm)imp25, an increase in surface area due to the additional impregnation can be observed. XRD analysis was performed for seven samples to determine the influence of the method of mixed oxide synthesis, the temperature of its modification, and tin amount on its phase composition. Two diffraction lines can be observed at approximately 2θ equals 43° and 63° typical for Periclase (MgO) derived from the hydrotalcite structure by calcination to form a mixed oxide ( Fig. 2). If the hydrotalcite was prepared by the co-precipitation method (10Sn-MOcpm and 5Sn-(10Sn-MOcpm)imp25), the characteristic diffraction lines for Romarchite at 2θ equals 29°, 33°, 51°, and 57° corresponding to the SnO and SnO2 states can be observed on the Fig. 2. It is a kind of SnO-SnO2 transition phase. The presence of this transition state could explain the cleavage of Romarchite at 2θ equals 29°. When the hydrotalcite was impregnated with any amount of tin (both at room temperature and 80 °C), the SnO2 diffraction lines were not observed. In N₂ physisorption measurements at 77 K, the shape of adsorption/desorption isotherms can provide information about the shape and structure of the pores of porous material. Adsorption/desorption isotherms, from which the specific surface area SBET was subsequently calculated were measured for all prepared catalysts. For some selected catalysts, the pore size distribution was also evaluated using NDFT. Fig. 3 a) shows adsorption/desorption isotherms of mixed oxides impregnated with 3 different amounts of tin (1,5,10Sn-MO2imp25), mixed oxide prepared by the coprecipitation method (10Sn-MOcpm) and also 10Sn-MOcpm modified by impregnation of 5% of tin (5Sn-(10Sn-MOcpm)imp25). The slight increase in the adsorbed amount in the micropore area can be noticed. However, the chosen method is not suitable for the study of micropores. The presence of mesopores is confirmed by the existence of a hysteresis loop. The isotherms are of type IV, which is typical for mesoporous materials. Based on the type of hysteresis curve, the pore shape can be concluded as type H3 characteristic of clay materials formed by randomly oriented plates. The pore size distribution of the samples was also determined ( Fig. 3 b)). The catalysts 10Sn-MO2imp25 and 5Sn-(10Sn-MOcpm)imp25 contain pores with a size of 5.5 nm. Furthermore, a relatively wide distribution of pores is observed in the area from 6 to 30 nm. A maximum of 9.5 nm can be observed for 1Sn-MO2imp25, 10.1 and 11.8 nm for 5Sn-MO2imp25 and 12.9 nm for 10Sn-MO2imp25 and 5Sn-(10Sn-MOcpm)imp25. Therefore, it can be concluded that the size of the pores also increases with the increasing amount of Sn. Concerning 10Sn-MOcpm catalyst, the maximum cannot be clearly determined, and the sample contains a wide distribution of pores from 9 nm to 50 nm. It is probably associated with the different methods of synthesis of this catalyst. During the co-precipitation method of synthesis, tin is incorporated into the forming structure of hydrotalcite at the moment of its preparation. Therefore, unlike the impregnation method, it does not block the pores, leading to a broader pores distribution. Table 2 shows the specific surface area of chosen mixed oxides with different concentrations of tin calculated using the BET equation and the NLDFT method. It can be seen that the results are very similar. The specific surface area of the 10Sn-MOcpm sample is slightly lower than other studied ones. It ranges from 150 to 275 m2/g, which would correspond to the values achieved for these types of materials. However, no dependence is observed with increasing tin concentration. This can also be confirmed by the data given in Table 1. It can also be seen from Table 2 that, as expected, the total pore volume decreases with an increasing amount of tin. To find out the differences in the morphology of the catalysts prepared by the impregnation and coprecipitation method and modified at different temperatures, SEM images were taken. Fig. 4 shows photos from the SEM, where the presence of flakes forming the relief of the catalyst surface can be observed. This indicates the presence of Mg-Al mixed oxide that was prepared from the double-layered hydroxide. It also confirms the type of hysteresis loop H3, which is typical for randomly oriented layers. Furthermore, the surface composition (metal distribution) of the catalysts was determined by EDS analysis ( Fig. 5 ). An inhomogeneous Sn distribution can be observed for the Sn-MOcpm samples. Tin forms clusters clearly visible in the EDS maps (samples a), b)). Homogeneous distribution of Sn is visible on the surface of the 5Sn-MO2imp25 and 5Sn-MO2imp80 catalysts without obvious cluster formation (samples c), d)). It is probably connected with the fact that for catalysts prepared by the co-precipitation method, tin is incorporated into the hydrotalcite structure inside the particle. Therefore only larger clusters are visible on its surface. On the other hand, tin is applied to the surface of the prepared catalyst during impregnation; thus, its uniform distribution on the surface of the particle can be seen from EDS records. No clusters of aluminium and magnesium are visible, and a homogeneous distribution of metals can be observed. 3.2 Catalytic testing All prepared tin-modified mixed oxides were tested as catalysts for Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of myrtenal to 6,6-dimethyl-bicycklo[1,3]-hept-2-en-2-ol formate and its subsequent hydrolysis to nopinone (Fig. 1). Sn-MCM-41 catalyst, which was also tested for this reaction, was chosen in order to compare the results with the literature [26]. Based on the literature[31], a temperature of 80 °C, hydrogen peroxide (50% solution) as an oxidizing agent, and 5Sn-MO2imp25 as a catalyst were chosen for initial experiments. Other reaction conditions such as temperature, oxidizing agent and its dosing method, and suitable solvents were applied. Different types of catalysts, the influence of their synthesis methods, modification and amount of impregnated tin, and the possibility of repeated use of the selected catalyst were tested. Finally, the experiment was carried out on a 10-fold enlarged scale. At first, the effect of type of oxidizing agent, its amount and dosing method on the course of the BV oxidation of myrtenal was studied. If meta-chloroperoxybenzoic acid (m-CPBA) was used as an oxidizing agent and a mixed oxide modified by impregnation (5Sn-MO2imp25) as a catalyst, a conversion of myrtenal (X) higher than 90% was achieved after only 10 min of reaction. The main product at the beginning of the reaction was formate, which was gradually transformed into nopinone over time ( Table 3 , exp. 1). The presence of formate in the reaction mixture was detected throughout the experiment (Sf). The selectivity to the desired products (Sn+f), including nopinone and formate, did not change over time and was in the 63 ± 2% range. The main by-products were myrtenol, formed from myrtenal, nopinol, formed from nopinone and myrtenic acid. When using a combination of m-CPBA with Sn-MCM-41 catalyst (Table 3 , exp. 2), almost two times lower myrtenal conversion values were achieved. The selectivity to the desired products did not exceed 30% after 5 h of reaction. The main products of the reaction were myrtenol and nopinol as well. If a mixed oxide prepared by the coprecipitation method (10Sn-MOcpm) was used as a catalyst in the presence of m-CPBA (Table 3 , exp. 3), the reaction proceeded slightly slower compared to 5Sn-MO2imp25, but after 5 h of reaction, higher values of both myrtenal conversion, i.e., 98%, and selectivity to the desired products, namely 87%, were achieved. However, the presence of formate was not already detected in the reaction mixture for the entire experiment duration. All the emerging formate was immediately hydrolyzed to nopinone. A similar reaction course was also observed when a solution of hydrogen peroxide (30% and 50%) was used as an oxidizing agent (Fig. 1 S). The dosage method fundamentally influences the reaction course. First, the same molar amount of 50% hydrogen peroxide solution as m-CPBA dosed all at once at the beginning of the reaction was tried. It can be seen from Table 3 (Exp. 4) that the maximum conversion achieved was only 10% after 5 h of reaction. The selectivity to nopinone (Sn) was approximately 76%; the major by-product was myrtenic acid. Hydrogen peroxide tends to decompose at higher temperatures. Its decomposition seems to be the cause of the low conversions. Therefore, other methods of dosing hydrogen peroxide into the reaction mixture were tested. The required amount of H2O2 was divided into several doses either 0.1 ml dosed at 30-minute intervals (Table 3 , exp. 5) or 0.05 ml dosed at 10-minute intervals (Table 3 , exp. 6). Such changes in dosage profiles had a very positive effect on myrtenal conversion. The best results were obtained when dosing at 10-minute intervals, namely 46% conversion and 88% selectivity to nopinone (Table 3 , exp. 6). Therefore such H2O2 dosing method was chosen as the most suitable for further experiments. Subsequently, the effect of the oxidizing agent amount was investigated. When applied 3.2 and 4.0 equivalents of hydrogen peroxide to myrtenal (Table 3 , exp. 8 and 9), the resulting values of both myrtenal conversion and selectivity to nopinone are very similar. After 5 h of the reaction, the conversion was almost total, and the selectivities to the desired product were around 90%. Using a lower amount of hydrogen peroxide led to a significant slowing down of the reaction rate expressed by the dependence of myrtenal conversion on time. Therefore, 3.2 eq. was chosen as the most appropriate amount of oxidizing agent for the following experiments. Experiments were also carried out using a 30% hydrogen peroxide solution (Table 3 , exp. 10). After 5 h of reaction, significantly lower conversion was achieved, namely only 76% compared to 99% in the case of a 50% solution (Table 3 , exp. 8). The selectivity to nopinone was not influenced by H2O2 concentration as expected. Finally, the effect of the type of oxidizing agent was tested in the absence of a catalyst. Initially, experiments were performed with m-CPBA as an oxidizing agent ( Table 4 , exp. 1 and 2). When comparing the results achieved after 1 h of reaction with the literature [26], the values of both conversions and selectivities were very similar. It should be mentioned that even if the reaction was carried out for 5 h, the values of the achieved conversion almost did not change and were around 18%. The selectivity also remained constant at approximately 60%. When the reactions were carried out by hydrogen peroxide as an oxidizing agent dosed in the entire amount at once and without catalyst, BV oxidation of myrtenal almost did not occur, both with 1.6 and 3.2 eq. of H2O2 (Table 4 , exp. 3 and 4). Slightly better results, 35% conversion of myrtenal and 88% selectivity to nopinone after 5 h of reaction, were obtained if the hydrogen peroxide was dosed at 10-minute intervals of 0.05 ml (Table 4 , exp. 5). It can be concluded that the presence of a catalyst in the reaction mixture is necessary for the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of myrtenal to nopinone to achieve high conversion. Therefore, the influence of the catalyst type, its modification method and the amount of introduced metal was subsequently studied. A 50% hydrogen peroxide solution of 3.2 eq. to myrtenal dosed in 10-minute intervals of 0.05 ml was chosen as the oxidizing agent for the following experiments. Based on the results described in the literature [31], it was assumed that the presence of tin incorporated into the mixed oxide structure, either by impregnation or co-precipitation, is necessary for Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of aldehyde. Therefore, the influence of the amount of tin impregnated at room temperature on a mixed oxide with a Mg/Al ion molar ratio of 2 (MO2) was investigated first. The results obtained from the reactions carried out in the presence of this mixed oxide modified 0.5 to 10 wt% of tin are very similar, both in terms of conversion and selectivity ( Table 5 , exp. 8–11, 14–15). Such results correspond to the textural properties mentioned in Table 2, where no dependence of the specific surface area on increasing tin concentration was observed and SBET values were very similar for mixed oxides containing different amounts of tin. The conversion of myrtenal was higher than 94% when catalyzed by hydrotalcite-based material, and the selectivities to nopinone were around 92 ± 4% except for hydrotalcite with Mg/Al ion ratio of 2 and containing 5 wt% tin, which was not calcined after impregnation (Table 5 , exp. 12). The maximum conversion of myrtenal, which was achieved over this catalyst, was only 68% after 5 h of reaction. Since the modification of the mixed oxide takes place in a methanol-water solution, partial rehydration and renewal of the hydrotalcite structure may occur. It was assumed that this process could have been the cause of the lower achieved conversions. Therefore, rehydration of the 5Sn-MO2imp25 catalyst was intentionally performed according to the procedure described in the experimental part. However, the results obtained from the reaction carried out in the presence of rehydrated hydrotalcite did not differ much from those obtained using mixed oxides, namely 96% conversion of myrtenal and 93% selectivity to nopinone (Table 5 , exp. 13). Furthermore, the effect of the molar ratio of Mg/Al ions on the course of BV oxidation of myrtenal was studied. Mixed oxides of magnesium-aluminum ion molar ratios of 2.0–3.5 range impregnated with 5 wt% of tin were used. When using mixed oxides MO2 and MO3, almost total conversion of myrtenal was achieved after 5 h of reaction, and the course of the reaction was very similar (Table 5 , exp. 11 and 21). Almost 10% lower conversion values were achieved over MO2.5 catalyst (Table 5 , exp. 16), and the lowest conversions were obtained over MO3.5, only 83% after 5 h of reaction (Table 5 , exp. 23). Such results could be caused by the basicity of the prepared catalysts (Table 1), as the basicity of mixed oxides decreases in the order MO2 >MO3 >MO2.5 >MO3.5 and is almost 2x lower for MO3.5 compared to MO2. The selectivity to nopinone was similar for all 4 catalysts and was approx. 90%. The influence of the temperature at which the modification of the mixed oxide by tin was studied as well. MO3 impregnated with 3 and 5 hm. % of tin was chosen for these experiments. The temperature at which the impregnation took place was either room temperature or 80 °C. The temperature of the modification had no significant effect either on the course of the reactions or on the resulting values of myrtenal conversion and selectivity to nopinone (Table 5 , exp 19–22). The obtained results are also supported by the very similar morphology of tin-modified hydrotalcites at different temperatures (Fig. 4 , samples c) and d)). The course of the reaction catalyzed by 3Sn-MO3imp80 varied slightly, as a conversion achieved 61% was after only 2 h of reaction. However, this trend was not observed for MO3 modified by 5 hm. % tin. Interesting results were achieved over a mixed oxide modified with tin by the co-precipitation method. This catalyst was used in three forms: calcined (10Sn-MOcpm), uncalcined (10Sn-HTcpm), and calcined and additionally modified by impregnation of 5 wt% of tin (5Sn-(10Sn-MOcpm)imp25) (Table 5 , exp. 24–26). Unlike 5Sn-HT2imp25 and 5Sn-MO2imp25, when using uncalcined 10Sn-HTcpm, almost 2x higher myrtenal conversion values were achieved than when using calcined 10Sn-MOcpm, namely 83% after 5 h of reaction versus 44%. On the other hand, the selectivity decreased due to the formation of a higher amount of myrtenic acid. After modification of 10Sn-MOcpm with 5 wt% of tin, the results were similar to those obtained under 5Sn-MO2imp25 catalysis, where almost total conversion of myrtenal and 92% selectivity to nopinone were achieved. Such difference in results between 10Sn-MOcpm and 5Sn-(10Sn-MOcpm)imp25 can be explained by the nearly 1.5-fold higher specific surface area of the 5Sn-(10Sn-MOcpm)imp25 catalyst similar to the SBET of tin-impregnated mixed oxides (Table 2). Due to the fact that no significant differences in results of BV oxidation were observed under catalysis by tin-impregnated mixed oxides, non-tin-modified hydrotalcites were tested as catalysts in calcined, uncalcined and rehydrated form. From the obtained results listed in Table 5 (Exp. 5–7), it can be concluded that the presence of tin incorporated into the hydrotalcite structure is not essential compared to BV oxidation of another aldehyde citral [31]. This fact could be explained by differences in molecule structure of linear and bicyclic aldehyde Almost total conversion of myrtenal and higher than 93% selectivity to nopinone were achieved using all of the above catalysts unmodified by tin. The only exception was the rehydrated hydrotalcite rHT2, with slightly lower selectivity, 86%, compared to the others. Finally, magnesium and aluminum oxides themselves were tested as catalysts (Table 5 , exp. 1–4). In general, almost 2x higher conversion of 95% was achieved under MgO catalysis than when Al2O3 was used. Two reasons could explain this either the form of the materials or the basicity. When Al2O3 was used in the form of a very fine powder, despite intense stirring, it tended to settle down at the bottom of the flask and was not reliably dispersed in the reaction mixture. Of the three types of Al2O3 used (neutral, acid, basic), the best results were achieved with acid oxide, almost 60%. The selectivity to nopinone in the case of both MgO and Al2O3 was around 90%. The second reason is the basicity of MgO. Its presence seems to be crucial for the catalysis of myrtenal BV oxidation to nopinone. This fact may be supported by results obtained over mixed oxides, and over Sn-MCM-41 catalyst without MgO component. Using Sn-MCM-41 catalyst, lower conversion and selectivity were achieved. For comparison with the literature[26], Sn-MCM-41 was also used as a catalyst (Table 5 , exp. 27). Corma et al.[26] reported 40% conversion of myrtenal and 93% selectivity to the desired products after only 1 h of reaction and using 1.5 eq. of H2O2 to myrtenal. In our study, we reached 50% conversion, but only after 5 h of reaction and using 3.2 eq. of H2O2. Selectivity to desired products was comparable with Corma study. In general, it can be stated that catalysts based on either hydrotalcites themselves or mixed oxides obtained from them are much more suitable and effective for the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of myrtenal than materials based on zeolites [26] or MCM-41. The effect of reaction temperature on the course of BV oxidation of myrtenal was investigated as well. Four temperatures were tested: 20, 40, 60 and 80 °C. It can be seen from Table 6, that at temperatures lower than 80 °C the reaction either almost did not proceed or the reaction rate expressed as a dependence of the starting substance conversion on time was much slowed down. Lower temperatures also negatively affected the selectivity to nopinone, although, at such low conversions, the selectivity values cannot be considered reliable. To investigate the influence of solvent type on the course of BV oxidation of myrtenal, a wide range of solvents differing in their properties, which are listed in Table 7, were chosen. Based on polarity expressed by the dielectric constant, acidity expressed by pKa values, and basicity represented by the donor number, trends were searched to explain the choice of a suitable solvent. If divide all used solvents into individual groups according to their characteristic properties, clear trends can be found in Table 7. For example, for the group of hydrocarbons (hexane, benzene, toluene) it is visible that with a slightly increasing polarity expressed by the dielectric constant and with a decreasing pKa value, the values of myrtenal conversion and selectivity to nopinone slightly increase. A similar trend can be found for groups of amides (DMF, DMA), nitriles (benzonitrile, acetonitrile) and solvents containing an oxygen-heteroatom bond (nitrobenzene, DMSO), where the conversion of the starting substance increases with increasing polarity of the solvent, but, unlike hydrocarbons, higher myrtenal conversion values were achieved using solvents with higher pKa and DN values. In general, the use of amide or nitrile solvents led to high values of myrtenal conversion (≥ 70%) and selectivity to nopinone (≥ 80%). Similar very good results were also achieved using cyclohexanol (90% conversion and 85% selectivity). Very low selectivity to nopinone was achieved in other alcohols used. Table 7 shows again how the conversion of the starting substance increases with increasing polarity in the order of isopropyl alcohol – ethanol – methanol. For the remaining two groups, chlorinated derivatives of hydrocarbons (DCM and chloroform) and ethers (MTBE, diethyl ether, THF and 1,4-dioxane), the indicated trend is exactly the opposite. For given groups of solvents, it can be seen how the conversion of myrtenal increases with decreasing solvent polarity. The selectivity in this case did not exceed 70%. Myrtenic acid was the main and only by-product in all solvents used. Considering the first mechanism of BV oxidation described in the Introduction of this study, good results using nitrile solvents were expected. On the other hand, it can be seen from Table 7 that very good results were also achieved in other solvents. This fact confirms the assumption that BV oxidation on tin-modified hydrotalcites also operates by the second described mechanism. Since the most suitable solvent for BV oxidation of myrtenal is acetonitrile, the influence of the amount of this solvent on the course of the reaction was subsequently tested. In addition, a solvent-free experiment was also performed. It can be seen from Table 8 that the reaction proceeded more slowly if the amount of solvent increased. When the amount of solvent was increased to 4.5 g, the conversion achieved only 96% after 5 h of reaction. If the reaction was carried out in 1.5 g of acetonitrile, total conversion was achieved after 2 h of reaction. The absence of solvent resulted in lower values of both myrtenal conversion and selectivity to nopinone. The selectivity in the presence of solvent in the reaction mixture was not affected by its amount and was around 90%. However, when the reaction was carried out without solvent, the selectivity values to nopinone were lowered by the myrtenic acid formed in a higher amount. Based on the results, an amount of acetonitrile corresponding to 1.5 mass equivalents to myrtenal was chosen as the most suitable. One of the advantages of heterogeneous catalysts is the possibility of their reuse. Also, in this work, there was an effort to reuse the catalysts. Two methods of reuse were tested: drying and calcination. Due to the possible losses of the catalytic mass during the processing of the reaction mixture after the reaction, the 1st cycle of BV oxidation was performed on a 10x larger scale ( Table 9). After the first reaction cycle, the catalyst was filtered off and washed with acetonitrile. Subsequently, the catalyst was dried overnight at a temperature of 110 °C. One half of the catalyst was used after such washing and drying (Drying), and the second half of the catalyst was further calcined at 400 °C under air for 5 h (Calcination). In order to note the variation in the results obtained using the recycled catalyst, an experiment on the same scale was carried out also with a fresh catalyst. The course of the reaction over fresh and calcined catalysts in the 2nd reaction cycle differed only within the experimental measurement mistake, 70 resp. 76% conversion of myrtenal was achieved after 5 h of the reaction. The selectivity was not affected and was around 87%. If the catalyst was only washed with solvent after the reaction and dried, it showed a slightly higher activity after 4–5 h of the second reaction cycle (Table 9). 85% conversion of myrtenal was achieved, and the selectivity to nopinone was also higher, around 98%. It could be related to hydrotalcite structure partially formed by rehydration during BV oxidation. This structure is then decomposed to mixed oxide during calcination at 400 °C. Based on these results, it can be concluded that the catalyst can be reused at least once and does not lose its activity during recycling. If the used catalyst is only dried, the reaction reaches higher conversion values than if the catalyst was also calcined. Catalysts after the second reaction cycle were filtered off and recycled again. The procedure for preparing the catalysts for the 3rd reaction cycle was the same as after the first cycle, i.e., the catalysts were washed with acetonitrile and dried overnight at a temperature of 110 °C. One half was used as follows (Drying-Drying, Calcination-Drying) and the second half was calcined under the same conditions (Drying-Calcination; Calcination-Calcination). Due to more significant mass losses during recycling, the third cycle of reactions took place on a smaller scale. For comparison on this scale, an experiment was also performed with a fresh catalyst. Quite interesting results were obtained after 3rd reaction cycle. From Table 9, an apparent positive effect of simply washing the catalyst with solvent and drying can be observed, regardless of whether it was dried or calcined after the first reaction cycle. After 2 h of reaction, 92% conversion was already achieved, while when using catalysts calcined after the 2nd reaction cycle, only 53% conversion (Washing-Calcination) or 67% conversion (Calcination-Calcination) was achieved after 2 h of reaction. A similarly low value was also achieved in the case of calcined referential fresh catalyst, namely 50%. From this it can be concluded that the partial rehydration of the mixed oxide and the renewal of the layered hydrotalcite structure occurring during the reaction and remaining during only drying, without subsequent calcination, has a positive effect both on the conversion of the starting substance and on the selectivity to nopinone. The selectivity was not significantly affected by repeated use of the catalysts, ranging from 92 – 98%. The lowest selectivity values were achieved with the catalyst (Wash-Calcination). From the measured data, it can be concluded that the catalyst can be used repeatedly, at least in three cycles. Catalyst activity does not significantly decrease with either method of recycling. Washing with a solvent and drying the catalyst after the reaction positively affected its activity in the following reaction cycle. There was an effort to characterize the catalysts that were recycled. Using XRF analysis, it was found that the metal ratio in the catalysts did not change, and SnO2 did not wash out. However, further investigation was impossible because the catalysts contained a large amount of organic impurities from the reaction. Thus, on the basis of the obtained results, it can be concluded that, compared to the literature [26], hydrotalcite-based catalysts are much more active, not only for the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of myrtenal itself, but mainly also for the subsequent hydrolysis of the resulting formate to the desired nopinone. Prepared and variously modified hydrotalcite-based catalysts allow both steps of the reaction to be carried out in a "one-pot" format and to achieve not only total conversion of the starting material, but also a very high 93% selectivity to the desired ketone, only after 2 h from the start of the reaction. The great advantage of these materials for the BV oxidation of myrtenal to nopinone is their applicability in unmodified form and moreover they are recyclable. Since the recycling process only involves washing the used catalyst and drying it at relatively low temperatures (110 °C), the use of hydrotalcites as catalysts reduces the cost of the production process several times. Among other things, the synthesis of hydrotalcites is a relatively simple, cheap and fast process and all starting materials are commercially available, which puts hydrotalcites far ahead of zeolites or mesoporous materials described in the literature. 4 Conclusions Mixed oxides modified with tin either by impregnation or coprecipitation were prepared, analysed by available analytical methods, and tested as catalysts for the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of myrtenal to form formate and its subsequent hydrolysis to nopinone. The influence of the type of oxidizing agent, its amount and dosing method, effect of reaction temperature, type and amount of solvent was studied. However, the primary focus of study was to assess the effect of the type of catalyst, the method of its modification and the amount of metal that was incorporated into the structure of the catalyst. A scale-up experiment was carried out under the chosen most suitable reaction conditions. Last but not least, the possibility of repeated use of the prepared catalysts was tested. Several conclusions can be drawn from all the analyses performed and the data obtained. A 50% hydrogen peroxide solution is a suitable oxidizing agent for BV oxidation of myrtenal when dosed at 10 min intervals in a total amount corresponding to 3.2 equivalents to myrtenal. A temperature of 80 °C and acetonitrile as solvent in an amount of three weight equivalents to myrtenal appear to be the most suitable reaction conditions. However, only one suitable catalyst was not chosen for the studied reaction. It can be stated that to achieve high values of myrtenal conversion and selectivity to nopinone, the structure of the catalyst corresponding to hydrotalcite or a mixed oxide based on hydrotalcites, whether with SnO2 content or not is important. The catalyst can be used repeatedly without losing its activity, in at least three reaction cycles. A scale-up resulted in a slower reaction rate. Under chosen appropriate reaction conditions and in the presence of 5Sn-MO2imp25 as a catalyst, a total conversion of myrtenal and a selectivity to nopinone of 93% was achieved after 2 h of reaction. coredata.dc:description: Nopinone is a fine chemical used in many areas of the chemical industry. A relatively new method of its synthesis is Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of myrtenal to 6,6-dimethyl-bicyclo[3,1,1]-hept-2-en-2-ol formate and its subsequent hydrolysis to nopinone. This study deals with preparing mixed oxides modified with tin and tested them as catalysts for this reaction. Besides the influence of different reaction conditions, the research was aimed at the influence of the catalyst type, the method of its modification and the amount of metal incorporated into its structure. The possibility of repeated use of the prepared catalysts was also tested. Total conversion of myrtenal and selectivity to nopinone of 93% was achieved after 2 h of the reaction using the catalyst based on mixed oxide with the molar ratio of Mg/Al ions equals 2 modified by 5 wt% of tin. This catalyst can be used repeatedly in at least three reaction cycles.
coredata.dc:title: Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of myrtenal over hydrotalcites based catalysts: The role of structure type, metal content, preparation method and acid-base properties
